body.p:
Lexington Sep. 8. 1863
Gov T. E. Bramlett
Dear Sir

James Maloy arrested some months since for stealing 3 horses from this County, was indicted by the Grand Jury & confined in Jail. In July he formed a conspiracy with several others to Break jail. He & another prisoner named Barnes, since captured, & convicted on a similar charge succeeded in making their escape under very agravating circumstances, for in my resisting their attented escape I was very badly injured myself.
not however until I had succeeded in killing one & dangerously wounding another of the party. I offered a reward of $50 for his arrest, which is as much as I can afford being a poor man.
I now have information from the marshal of Covington that if an additional reward of $50 is offered he can be captured & brought to justice.
Maloy is a notorious thief and is one of a gang also have been extensively engaged in Horse stealing in this region for months He should be made an example of & I write to request you
to offer a reward of $50 on the part of the state

Most Respectfully
W. H. Leesby
Jailor Fayette Co
